Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Nanoscribe 3D Laser Lithography System

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation proposal will support the acquisition of a three-dimensional (3D) printer with nanoscale resolution. The advent of 3D printing has provided researchers with an unprecedented ability to realize and test new concepts, by enabling the simple and rapid fabrication of 3D prototypes. However, one of the major limitations of nearly all existing 3D printing techniques, is they are limited to resolutions of about 15 microns. This is a severe issue, as many device concepts, experimental research approaches, and emergent material properties only become possible with the capability to fabricate 3D structures with nanoscale features. By printing structures with features over 40 times smaller than the diameter of a human blood cell and 100 times smaller than other existing 3D printers, the acquisition of a Nanoscribe 3D printer will enable a large and diverse array of new research with impacts ranging from aerospace to biomedical applications, such as: new ultra-light materials that can be tailored for energy absorption, or sub-cellular nanostructures for new clinical therapies and tissue engineering. This program will also support an array of new educational activities focused on nanoscale 3D printing, ranging from K-12 to graduate levels, which will help develop the future STEM workforce and increase the participation of underrepresented students.

The Nanoscribe 3D printer, with an in-plane resolution of 150 nm and an out-of-plane resolution of 1 micron, will enable a wide array of new integrative and transformative research. Emergent material properties stemming from microstructural geometry will be studied, such as dynamic tunability or combined low-density, high-stiffness, and high damping. Novel 3D microfluidic anisotropic ratchet conveyor systems for biological assays and combinatorial chemistry will be explored. The Nanoscribe instrument will allow unprecedented investigations into the effect of 3D nanotopography on cell development, function, and mechanics. New ultra-compact optical beam shaping systems will be investigated, including 3D diffractive optical traps and metasurfaces. The Nanoscribe instrument will also serve as a platform to study new photocurable resins for nanoscale 3D printing that expand the library of printable materials and enable higher resolution printing. New microscale flying robotic concepts will be studied that leverage 3D sub- microscale structural elements. Finally, the Nanoscribe instrument will also open the study of 3D printing for use in otolaryngological microsurgical applications to improve hearing. As is demonstrated by the diverse research objectives of the 17 senior personnel leading this program, the acquisition of this state-of-the-art 3D nanofabrication capability will be a major regional resource, and lead to a broad range of new research in the greater Pacific Northwest community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The advent of 3D printing has provided researchers with an unprecedented ability to realize and test new concepts, by enabling the simple and rapid fabrication of 3D prototypes. However, one of the major limitations of nearly all existing 3D printing techniques, is they are limited to resolutions of ~15 μm. This is a severe issue, as many device concepts, experimental approaches, and emergent material properties only become possible via the capability to fabricate 3D structures with sub-microscale features.

This proposal was for the acquisition of a Nanoscribe three-dimensional (3D) laser lithography system. The Nanoscribe is the highest resolution 3D printer that is currently commercially available, with an in-plane resolution of 150 nm and an out-of-plane resolution of 1 μm. The Nanoscribe instrument has been housed at the University of Washington Nanofabrication Facility (WNF), part of the NSF-funded National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) network. Since its installation, the facility has become a regional resource for research in the Pacific Northwest, drawing users from other universities and private industry. So far, more than 20 research groups from the University of Washington (UW), spanning over 9 departments, have taken advantage of the Nanoscribe to further their research spectrum and introduce the advantages of nano-additive manufacturing in their fields of research.

The acquisition of the Nanoscribe 3D laser lithography system has led to a plethora of transformational discoveries in the fields of advanced hierarchical materials and coatings, advanced structural composites, microfluidic systems, micro-robotics, and otolaryngology. For instance, thanks to its outstanding resolution, the Nanoscribe has enabled the development of material systems featuring Bouligand structures with characteristic sizes that are comparable to natural materials. This work is shedding new light on the hierarchical toughening mechanisms exhibited by this structure, as well as the scaling of material properties at multiple length scales towards engineering tougher materials out of intrinsically weak components. The facility has also enabled the study of ceramic and fractal nanolattices which is contributing to engineering more light weight, energy absorbing, and resilient materials. This project has also investigated nanoscale tensegrity structures for the formulation of highly deformable actuators as well as the manufacturing of photopolymer hydrogels for implantable biomedical devices, drug delivery, and cell scaffolding. Finally, the 3D laser lithography system has enabled the fabrication of alumina coatings based on spinodal shell which can enable the formulation of highly-deformable, scratch-resistant coatings with unprecedented physical properties.

The Nanoscribe instrument has provided regional users with access to a state-of-the-art 3D nanofabrication capability, and new interdisciplinary research facilitated by the WNF and the UW Advanced Materials & Additive Manufacturing Strategic Research Initiative. The instrument has proven to be an important new resource for UW undergraduate and graduate programs in Nanoscience. More than 60 graduate and undergraduate students have been trained on the Nanoscribe instrument since the start of the project. The cornerstone of our education and outreach plan included the creation of a new Vertically Integrated Project team (NSF funded program) called 3D Nano-Additive Manufacturing of Engineered Structures (3D-NAMES), that is focused on the nanoscale 3D printing; and the incorporation of the Nanoscribe instrument into the Burke Museum fossil digitalization effort. The acquisition of the Nanoscribe has been instrumental also to increase the involvement of underrepresented students in STEM. We have participated annually, through the creation of Nanoscribe-centered demonstration modules, in: the UW Engineering Discovery Days event, which hosts over 6000 K-12 students from Washington State; and the UW College of Engineering Summer Math Academy, a four-week high school residential program hosting students where the majority are from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. We discovered that nanoengineering is a great vehicle to disseminate engineering discoveries and to instill a passion for STEM in these young minds.

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2021
Modified by: Marco Salviato
